segment.source: Using the Microsoft C Runtime with User-Mode Drivers and Desktop Apps
segment.target: Using the Microsoft C Runtime with User-Mode Drivers and Desktop Apps

segment.source: [This topic applies only to desktop drivers and not universal drivers.]
segment.target: [This topic applies only to desktop drivers and not universal drivers.]

segment.source: This topic provides information about distributing the C Runtime Libraries with applications and drivers for Windows 8 and Windows 8.1.
segment.target: This topic provides information about distributing the C Runtime Libraries with applications and drivers for Windows 8 and Windows 8.1.

segment.source: It provides guidelines for user-mode driver and desktop application writers to compile their code, and package it for redistribution with the necessary C Runtime libraries.
segment.target: It provides guidelines for user-mode driver and desktop application writers to compile their code, and package it for redistribution with the necessary C Runtime libraries.

segment.source: The C runtime libraries (CRT) are no longer shipped as a Windows shared component
segment.target: The C runtime libraries (CRT) are no longer shipped as a Windows shared component

segment.source: In the past, Microsoft distributed the C runtime libraries (CRT) as a Window shared system component.
segment.target: In the past, Microsoft distributed the C runtime libraries (CRT) as a Window shared system component.

segment.source: In previous versions of the WDK, you could link your code with the Windows System version of the CRT when you built your driver or traditional Windows app.
segment.target: In previous versions of the WDK, you could link your code with the Windows System version of the CRT when you built your driver or traditional Windows app.

segment.source: With the release of Windows 8, the C Runtime libraries are no longer considered a system component, and you must ship a redistributable version of the CRT with your user-mode driver or desktop application.
segment.target: With the release of Windows 8, the C Runtime libraries are no longer considered a system component, and you must ship a redistributable version of the CRT with your user-mode driver or desktop application.

segment.source: This topic discusses the reasons for this change, the new components of the C Runtime, and strategies for building your desktop app or driver and redistributing the CRT.
segment.target: This topic discusses the reasons for this change, the new components of the C Runtime, and strategies for building your desktop app or driver and redistributing the CRT.

segment.source: Why did Microsoft make this change?
segment.target: Why did Microsoft make this change?

segment.source: There are now two separate versions of the C Runtime.
segment.target: There are now two separate versions of the C Runtime.

segment.source: One is an internal Windows component, and the other is for use by application and driver developers and ships with Visual Studio.
segment.target: One is an internal Windows component, and the other is for use by application and driver developers and ships with Visual Studio.

segment.source: The primary reasons for this change are for consistency and to support servicing of the CRT for customers.
segment.target: The primary reasons for this change are for consistency and to support servicing of the CRT for customers.

segment.source: In the past, applications were sometimes linked to versions of the CRT on computers that did not have the correct versions of the CRT DLL installed.
segment.target: In the past, applications were sometimes linked to versions of the CRT on computers that did not have the correct versions of the CRT DLL installed.

segment.source: Using a common public version of the CRT will help eliminate this problem.
segment.target: Using a common public version of the CRT will help eliminate this problem.

segment.source: In addition, servicing the CRT can be complex.
segment.target: In addition, servicing the CRT can be complex.

segment.source: The Visual C team plans to ship periodic updates of the CRT included with Visual Studio.
segment.target: The Visual C team plans to ship periodic updates of the CRT included with Visual Studio.

segment.source: By using the recommended redistribution strategies, you can easily pick up these changes for your application.
segment.target: By using the recommended redistribution strategies, you can easily pick up these changes for your application.

segment.source: Also, you will not have to worry about a change in the Windows System version of the CRT breaking your application.
segment.target: Also, you will not have to worry about a change in the Windows System version of the CRT breaking your application.

segment.source: The msvcrt.dll is now a system component owned and built by Windows.
segment.target: The msvcrt.dll is now a system component owned and built by Windows.

segment.source: It is intended for use only by system-level components.
segment.target: It is intended for use only by system-level components.

segment.source: The files msvcr110.dll (Visual Studio 2012) or msvcr120.dll (Microsoft Visual Studio 2013) are the new public versions of the CRT and are for use by Desktop application and user-mode driver developers.
segment.target: The files msvcr110.dll (Visual Studio 2012) or msvcr120.dll (Microsoft Visual Studio 2013) are the new public versions of the CRT and are for use by Desktop application and user-mode driver developers.

segment.source: Building your code with the C runtime
segment.target: Building your code with the C runtime

segment.source: Visual C++ installs the latest version of the CRT in the System32 directory on a development system.
segment.target: Visual C++ installs the latest version of the CRT in the System32 directory on a development system.

segment.source: This is installed as a convenience for the developer.
segment.target: This is installed as a convenience for the developer.

segment.source: Otherwise, all projects that are built with Visual C++ that link with the shared CRT require a copy of the DLL in the build directory for debugging and execution.
segment.target: Otherwise, all projects that are built with Visual C++ that link with the shared CRT require a copy of the DLL in the build directory for debugging and execution.

segment.source: The msvcr120.dll can be used for drivers that target Windows 8.1 and Windows 8 and previous versions of Windows (starting with Windows Vista).
segment.target: The msvcr120.dll can be used for drivers that target Windows 8.1 and Windows 8 and previous versions of Windows (starting with Windows Vista).

segment.source: Redistributing the C Runtime
segment.target: Redistributing the C Runtime

segment.source: When you build a user-mode driver or traditional Desktop application in Microsoft Visual Studio, and the application uses the C run-time libraries (CRT), you must distribute the appropriate CRT dynamic-link libraries.
segment.target: When you build a user-mode driver or traditional Desktop application in Microsoft Visual Studio, and the application uses the C run-time libraries (CRT), you must distribute the appropriate CRT dynamic-link libraries.

segment.source: The recommended strategy for redistributing the CRT depends on the type of application or driver you are building.
segment.target: The recommended strategy for redistributing the CRT depends on the type of application or driver you are building.

segment.source: For Windows 8 and Windows 8.1, Microsoft provides a Visual C++ Redistributable Package (VCRedist\_x86.exe, VCRedist\_x64.exe, VCRedist\_arm.exe) that is included with Visual Studio.
segment.target: For Windows 8 and Windows 8.1, Microsoft provides a Visual C++ Redistributable Package (VCRedist\_x86.exe, VCRedist\_x64.exe, VCRedist\_arm.exe) that is included with Visual Studio.

segment.source: Developers can chain the redistributable package in with their other binaries.
segment.target: Developers can chain the redistributable package in with their other binaries.

segment.source: If you use the redistributable package, the C/C++ Runtime can be serviced on the customer's computer automatically.
segment.target: If you use the redistributable package, the C/C++ Runtime can be serviced on the customer's computer automatically.

segment.source: If you want to achieve isolation, you can either link statically, or copy the specific Visual C/C++ DLLs to the application local folder along with their other binaries.
segment.target: If you want to achieve isolation, you can either link statically, or copy the specific Visual C/C++ DLLs to the application local folder along with their other binaries.

segment.source: An application local folder is a folder that contains an executable application file.
segment.target: An application local folder is a folder that contains an executable application file.

segment.source: DLLs must be deployed to the application local folder.
segment.target: DLLs must be deployed to the application local folder.

segment.source: The Visual C/C++ Redistributable Package (VCRedist\_\*.exe ) is serviced as an application.
segment.target: The Visual C/C++ Redistributable Package (VCRedist\_\*.exe ) is serviced as an application.

segment.source: If your installation includes the redistributable package, the latest version is installed in System32 upon initial setup, and updates are enabled using the Microsoft Update service, as a complete package.
segment.target: If your installation includes the redistributable package, the latest version is installed in System32 upon initial setup, and updates are enabled using the Microsoft Update service, as a complete package.

segment.source: All components of the Visual C/C++ Redistributable Package are updated as a single unit.
segment.target: All components of the Visual C/C++ Redistributable Package are updated as a single unit.

segment.source: If you copied individual CRT components to System32, without using redistributable package, these would not be serviced automatically, and may be overwritten accidentally.
segment.target: If you copied individual CRT components to System32, without using redistributable package, these would not be serviced automatically, and may be overwritten accidentally.

segment.source: A potential problem exists if a driver copies CRT components to System32 and another program runs the redistributable package, the version installed by the driver will be overwritten.
segment.target: A potential problem exists if a driver copies CRT components to System32 and another program runs the redistributable package, the version installed by the driver will be overwritten.

segment.source: The opposite case is also a potential problem.
segment.target: The opposite case is also a potential problem.

segment.source: If a program ran redistributable package and a driver copies an earlier version of CRT components into System32, this might break the application.
segment.target: If a program ran redistributable package and a driver copies an earlier version of CRT components into System32, this might break the application.

segment.source: The INF installation process simply checks the version number of the library to install against the one already in System32, and overwrites it if they are different.
segment.target: The INF installation process simply checks the version number of the library to install against the one already in System32, and overwrites it if they are different.

segment.source: Recommended Strategies
segment.target: Recommended Strategies

segment.source: Use the following strategies when redistributing the C/C++ run time components with your drivers and applications.
segment.target: Use the following strategies when redistributing the C/C++ run time components with your drivers and applications.

segment.source: For applications installed under Program Files:
segment.target: For applications installed under Program Files:

segment.source: Use the Visual C++ Redistributable Package (VCRedist\_x86.exe, VCRedist\_x64.exe, VCRedist\_arm.exe), which deploys the CRT under System32.
segment.target: Use the Visual C++ Redistributable Package (VCRedist\_x86.exe, VCRedist\_x64.exe, VCRedist\_arm.exe), which deploys the CRT under System32.

segment.source: In this case, the redistributable package can be updated automatically.
segment.target: In this case, the redistributable package can be updated automatically.

segment.source: Alternatively, install the DLL(s) to the application local directory (copied directly to the directory where the application is installed), or link statically to the CRT.
segment.target: Alternatively, install the DLL(s) to the application local directory (copied directly to the directory where the application is installed), or link statically to the CRT.

segment.source: In this case, the CRT would need to be serviced manually.
segment.target: In this case, the CRT would need to be serviced manually.

segment.source: For printer drivers:
segment.target: For printer drivers:

segment.source: These drivers should include the required CRT files in the INF, so the CRT files are copied to the driver store as part of the driver payload.
segment.target: These drivers should include the required CRT files in the INF, so the CRT files are copied to the driver store as part of the driver payload.

segment.source: V4 print drivers cannot use a co-installer for setup, so the INF must copy relevant binaries of the C/C++ runtime library to the driver store.
segment.target: V4 print drivers cannot use a co-installer for setup, so the INF must copy relevant binaries of the C/C++ runtime library to the driver store.

segment.source: To do this, you should reference the appropriate files in the \[COPY\_FILES\] section of the driver package.
segment.target: To do this, you should reference the appropriate files in the \[COPY\_FILES\] section of the driver package.

segment.source: V3 print drivers should not use co-installers for setup, as they are not run during Point and Print connections.
segment.target: V3 print drivers should not use co-installers for setup, as they are not run during Point and Print connections.

segment.source: These drivers should reference the appropriate files in the \[COPY\_FILES\] section of the driver package.
segment.target: These drivers should reference the appropriate files in the \[COPY\_FILES\] section of the driver package.

segment.source: The following is an example of how to include the CRT binaries in the \[COPY\_FILES\] section of an INF:
segment.target: The following is an example of how to include the CRT binaries in the \[COPY\_FILES\] section of an INF:

segment.source: Text
segment.target: Text

segment.source: [SourceDisksFiles]
segment.target: [SourceDisksFiles]

segment.source: Msvcr120.dll = 2
segment.target: Msvcr120.dll = 2

segment.source: ; other files
segment.target: ; other files

segment.source: [SourceDisksNames.amd64]
segment.target: [SourceDisksNames.amd64]

segment.source: 1 = %Location%,,,
segment.target: 1 = %Location%,,,

segment.source: 2 = %Location%,,,"amd64"
segment.target: 2 = %Location%,,,"amd64"

segment.source: For UMDF drivers:
segment.target: For UMDF drivers:

segment.source: Statically link your driver against the CRT to include the runtime in the binary.
segment.target: Statically link your driver against the CRT to include the runtime in the binary.

segment.source: In this case, you do not need to redistribute the CRT.
segment.target: In this case, you do not need to redistribute the CRT.

segment.source: Linking your code with the C Runtime libraries
segment.target: Linking your code with the C Runtime libraries

segment.source: The following libraries contain the C run-time library functions.
segment.target: The following libraries contain the C run-time library functions.

segment.source: Term
segment.target: Term

segment.source: Description
segment.target: Description

segment.source: Msvcr120.dll
segment.target: Msvcr120.dll

segment.source: C runtime.
segment.target: C runtime.

segment.source: Msvcp120.dll
segment.target: Msvcp120.dll

segment.source: C++ runtime.
segment.target: C++ runtime.

segment.source: Msvcr120d.dll
segment.target: Msvcr120d.dll

segment.source: Debug version of C runtime.
segment.target: Debug version of C runtime.

segment.source: No redistribution allowed.
segment.target: No redistribution allowed.

segment.source: Msvcp120d.dll
segment.target: Msvcp120d.dll

segment.source: Debug version of C++ runtime.
segment.target: Debug version of C++ runtime.

segment.source: No redistribution allowed.
segment.target: No redistribution allowed.

segment.source: To determine which DLLs you must redistribute with your application, you should collect a list of the DLLs that your application depends on.
segment.target: To determine which DLLs you must redistribute with your application, you should collect a list of the DLLs that your application depends on.

segment.source: One way to collect the list is to run Dependency Walker (depends.exe).
segment.target: One way to collect the list is to run Dependency Walker (depends.exe).

segment.source: When you have the list of dependencies, compare it to the list of files described in Redistributable Code for Visual Studio 2013 Preview and Visual Studio 2013 SDK Preview.
segment.target: When you have the list of dependencies, compare it to the list of files described in Redistributable Code for Visual Studio 2013 Preview and Visual Studio 2013 SDK Preview.

segment.source: For more information, see Determining Which DLLs to Redistribute and Choosing a Deployment Method.
segment.target: For more information, see Determining Which DLLs to Redistribute and Choosing a Deployment Method.

segment.source: You cannot redistribute all of the files that are included in Visual Studio; you are only permitted to redistribute the files that are specified in Redistributable Code for Visual Studio 2013 Preview and Visual Studio 2013 SDK Preview.
segment.target: You cannot redistribute all of the files that are included in Visual Studio; you are only permitted to redistribute the files that are specified in Redistributable Code for Visual Studio 2013 Preview and Visual Studio 2013 SDK Preview.

segment.source: Debug versions of applications and the various Visual C++ dynamic-link libraries are not redistributable.
segment.target: Debug versions of applications and the various Visual C++ dynamic-link libraries are not redistributable.

segment.source: Summary - What you need to do
segment.target: Summary - What you need to do

segment.source: Use the Visual C++ Redistributable Package (VCRedist\_x86.exe, VCRedist\_x64.exe, VCRedist\_arm.exe)VCRedist.msi as part of your installation process, if at all possible.
segment.target: Use the Visual C++ Redistributable Package (VCRedist\_x86.exe, VCRedist\_x64.exe, VCRedist\_arm.exe)VCRedist.msi as part of your installation process, if at all possible.

segment.source: For printer drivers, use desktop application local deployment of the CRT to the driver store.
segment.target: For printer drivers, use desktop application local deployment of the CRT to the driver store.

segment.source: For UMDF drivers, use static linking of the CRT with your driver code.
segment.target: For UMDF drivers, use static linking of the CRT with your driver code.

segment.target: Related topics
